Award.AwardTitle: Controlling and quantifying two-level systems, disorder and ideality in tetrahedrally bonded amorphous thin films
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Abstract

In the field of Condensed Matter Physics, materials that lack structural order -- deemed "amorphous materials" or "glasses" -- are, compared to crystals, relatively unexplored. Crystals consist of spatially repeated atoms, which permit mathematically simple formalisms that can be used to calculate and predict properties of these systems. Amorphous systems, however, have no such structural repeatability, and thus are less understood. This lack of understanding, however, does not preclude the applicability or scientific impact of disordered systems; plastics, silicate glasses, and amorphous silicon photovoltaics are examples that are pertinent to daily life, industry, and technologies. Amorphous superconductors are a remarkable example of how a fundamental scientific property transcends structural imperfection. The properties of a disordered material depend strongly on how the material was produced, but it is not clear how to describe the different amorphous structures produced by different methods, even for a single element material, nor what the nature of a defect is in a fully disordered material. It is clear that disorder exists on different length and energy scales, ranging from local, atomic-sized disorder to larger scales. Intriguingly, there exists the notion of an "ideal glass", which while remaining thoroughly disordered, lacks imperfections in that disorder and thus approaches the uniqueness of a crystal, including reproducibility and predictability of its properties. The project will determine the relationship between types of disorder and defects produced by different preparation methods and for different atoms, and the tunability of the "ideality" of disordered materials. Such a determination will yield improved understanding and control of disordered materials of technological and fundamental scientific significance. The project will also educate and train students and help to increase diversity participation in science; the PI and graduate student are women, and actively engage in efforts to make physics accessible to underrepresented STEM ethnic and socioeconomic minorities.

Technical Abstract

A problem of both longstanding and current interest is the thermodynamic nature of the amorphous or glassy state. The lack of structural order makes these systems less mathematically tractable and makes it a challenge to resolve how disorder affects the thermodynamic properties. Local and global minima on a broad scale (>>kT) in the energy landscape are relevant to the configurational entropy. An ideal glass has low configurational entropy, approaching that of the crystalline counterpart, thus implying the existence of a unique disordered state that lacks defects. Local minima on a much smaller scale (<10^5 K/sec) and cooling (>10^4 K/sec) rates of these calorimeters and wide temperature range permit these previously impossible experiments, including determination of zero temperature configurational entropy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the field of Condensed Matter Physics, materials that lack structural order, known as amorphous or disordered solids, are relatively unexplored when compared to crystals. Crystals are made of atoms whose positions are perfectly defined and periodic, allowing for calculations that predict their physical properties. Amorphous systems, however, have no such structural periodicity, and their physical properties are more difficult to predict and thus less understood. This lack of understanding, however, does not preclude the applicability or scientific impact of disordered systems; photovoltaics, quantum computing, and mirrors used for gravitational wave detection are examples that are pertinent to daily life, industry, and technologies. In all these applications, energy dissipation (mechanical and dielectric) is caused by small atomic motions in the disordered structure which are not found in ordered materials.  The properties of a disordered material depend strongly on how the material was produced, but it is not clear how to describe the different amorphous structures produced by different methods, even for a single element material, nor what the nature of a defect is in a fully disordered material. It is known that structural disorder exists on different length scales yielding different energy signatures, such as entropy, ranging from local, atomic-sized disorder to larger scales involving clusters of atoms. We studied these effects in amorphous silicon in order to identify what structures increase the dissipation of energy in the material, and how energy dissipation can be reduced through preparing better amorphous silicon, key factors for the technologies mentioned above.

We found that amorphous silicon shows a large dependence of atomic density with growth temperature, thickness and growth rate (from 95% down to 75% of the crystal silicon density). Thicker films, grown at higher temperatures and lower rates show the largest atomic densities, very close to the crystalline density. Short (< 1 nm) and medium (1 to 5 nm) range order measurements show that disorder (Dq) and strain are reduced in films grown at higher temperatures. The lower density films show increased disorder and a higher density of nanovoids. Films grown above a critical thickness reorganize and reduce the atomic disorder in the first layers that initially grew more disordered.  The images show the atomic density (a) and atomic disorder (b) as a function of thickness for samples grown at different thicknesses (black) and for initially thick samples whose top layers have been etched to obtain thinner films (teal).  Although atomic density shows no reorganization (a thick film etched back to a thin film has the density of the as-grown thin film) (a), which means that there is no film densification, the bond angle width Dqwhich measures atomic disorder shows the opposite effect (a thick film etched back to a thin film has the Dqof the thick film, not that of the as-grown thin film) (b), showing that atoms find a way to reorganize and reduce disorder with increasing thickness. This atomic reorganization causes a reduction in energy dissipation as the films grow thicker, such that the energy dissipation of thick films is less than that of a thinner film; these data make clear that atomic scale disorder (Dq) is more important than nanovoids in creating energy dissipation.  

The intellectual meritof this work is that we established a connection between the structure of amorphous silicon (atomic density, dangling bond density, short and medium range order) and energy dissipation in the form of mechanical losses, particularly those important at low temperatures.  We specifically found that to obtain amorphous silicon films with lower structural disorder and reduced mechanical or dielectric energy dissipation, these need to be thicker, grown at higher temperatures and at lower rates. These results provide a better understanding of the mechanisms that cause energy dissipation in amorphous solids, and what structural features enhance it in amorphous silicon.  The broader impactof this work is to provide a material which can be prepared with low energy loss, which is important to several technologies (superconducting qubits, LIGO mirror coatings, other optical devices) and we have increased the understanding of amorphous materials by connecting these low loss materials with the theoretical concept of an ideal glass, which is a low defect glass. A further broader impact lies in the education and research training of several students (undergraduate and graduate) and a postdoc, including one graduate student who completed her PhD with the support of this award, and now teaches at Cal State San Luis Obispo.  These students and postdoc were exposed to a wide range of scientists including from industry, academia, and national labs, both via research collaborations and at national conferences.  The students and the PI participated in several activities at UC Berkeley aimed at increasing the participation of underrepresented students from the broad Bay Area community.
